text: Hallo wereld.
Hoe is het?
We're the Vagabrothers
and this is a buddy
Hi!
Kelvin from Cinemates
And that's a canal!
Amsterdam has to be one of the coolest cities in the world.

It was the first place Mark and I visited
as 18 year old back packers on a Eurail trip
after high school.

We visited two years apart, but we did the
same thing... spent most of our time in the

fabled coffeeshops of the Red Light District
enjoying our newfound freedoms. We even sent
photos home to Mom and Dad to keep them happy.

A decade later, we returned to Amsterdam with
an older, somewhat more mature perspective.

We now realize that Amsterdam's tolerance
is a product of the city's democratic tradition

- a respect for the individual - and that
just because you're allowed to do some things,
doesn't mean you should.

Individual freedom is at the core of the city's
spirit, and has been since the Dutch Golden

Age in the 17th century, when Amsterdam was
a capital of world trade and finance and the

seat of empire that stretched from Asia to
the Caribbean.

And the wealth from that era built the city
we know today - concentric circles of canals

radiating out from the city center, each one
crossed by low bridges and lined with canal
houses.

In most cities, the highest buildings reflects
its most important institutions - often medieval

churches, princely towers, or the skyscrapers
of modern capitalism. But Amsterdam is different

– its three story townhouses are what make
this city such a pleasure to wander around.
The main streets in Amsterdam are really crowded.

Actually the main streets in Amsterdam are
canals.
This is true.

But the main streets are crowded and all you
have to do is hang a right hang a left, take

a couple of streets down off of the main one
and it's like super chill, quiet little canals.

Amsterdam is still a place where the whole
world comes together, and that is why we came

here. We were invited to stay with our friend
Wijnand Boon, a fellow traveler with an incredible

story. In 2010 he started walking across Europe,
from Amsterdam to Istanbul. It took him three
years to walk 10,000 km, or 6000 miles.

For three years he depended on the hospitality
of strangers, people he met on the internet,
using Facebook, Twitter and CouchSurfing.

He stayed with Mark in San Sebastian and me
in Galicia and then we didn't see or hear

from him for two years until our paths crossed
again on the last day of his journey in Istanbul.

For now, Wijnand has stopped wandering and
is living in the coolest house in Amsterdam,

a small cottage just a quick ferry ride across
the river from Amsterdam Centraal. He welcomed

us with a typical Dutch breakfast - sweet
bread from Friesland, toast with chocolate
sprinkles, fresh creamy milk and Edam cheese.

That afternoon, Wijnand and his girlfriend
Thysa took us out of the city to see more

of the country. The Netherlands is the third
most densely populated country in world and

taking a cruise around the countryside will
show you why.
What does the Netherlands mean?
The “Nether-lands”, the low lands.

We created land where there was no land before
by throwing sand into water and then creating
big piles and reclaiming land.

So basically 40% of the Netherlands is reclaimed
from the water.
So 40% of the Netherlands is a sand castle?

It's almost a sand castle although its flat
and below sea level.

Seeing all those small towns made us realize
that the Netherlands is so much more than
just Amsterdam.
What are these?
Puffs
Mini Dutch pancakes.
What is that?
Butter.
Oh wow.
They're hot, careful.
Wow. Put down that camera and try this.
Puffergees?
Poffertjes!
That was almost Spanish!

After sunset, we headed back to Amsterdam
to enjoy a typical dutch drink - a Jeneever,
the predecessor to modern Gin.
Cheers!
To Amsterdam.
To Amsterdam.
To good friends and fun times.

The 
next day we decided to explore the area around
our house, Amsterdam North, one of the fastest-changing
neighborhoods in the city.

We're at the NDSM Shipyard in the north of
Amsterdam. They've been building ships here

since the Dutch ruled the seas and it was
the largest ship yard in all of Europe until
it went bankrupt in the 1980s.

In the 90s local artists moved in here and
convinced the government to let them stay

and turn it into the creative hub of the city.
So we're here and we're going to go check
it out.
Let's do it.

Inside we met Amerens, a local photographer
based in NDSM who told us how the space came
to be.

My name is Amerens Hedwich, I'm a photographer
and you're now at the NDSM. It's an art city.

What you see behind me is part of the art
city.

The metal structure was built and then the
people could [say] I want this many square
meters and they could fill it in themselves.

I think there's about 280 people working in
the city and about 80 spaces

Then we came across a cool fashion start-up
called Two-O, where the owners told us a more
about their project.

We created this company in about 2011. So
we started to combine wood with gadgets that

we use right now like iPhones, Samsung cases
and designs for sunglasses made out of wood.
Also bow ties, wooden bow ties.
Two-0, check them out. Stylish clothes.

After spending two days exploring the countryside
and Amsterdam North, it was time to go back

to the city to meet up with two more friends
- Peter and Kelvin, the talented duo behind
the hilarious YouTube channel Cinemates.

Peter and Kelvin are originally from the North
of the Netherlands but they came to Amsterdam

a year and a half ago to bring their project
to the next level. So over a beer we asked
Kelvin why he loves living in Amsterdam.

According to like artists and filmmakers and
entrepreneurs and designers, everything comes

together right here. And I don't think there
are lots of places in the world where it's
so vibrant.

One thing I noticed about this city is that
when you're walking around you really have

to pay attention because there is so much
happening. There is a tram coming at you there's

500 people on bicycles if you step in the
bike lane here it's the biggest faux pas.
You're not allowed to do that.

One lesson. Don't walk in the red paths. The
red lanes are bicycle lanes and everything
apart from that is for pedestrians.

Don't walk in the red lanes and don't walk
in the red lights.

Speaking of the red light district everyone
does associate it with prostitution and that

makes sense because that's why it's called
the red light district. But if you look beside

the whores there are lots of actually very
cozy, gezellig cafes.
Can you explain that word for us? Gezellig?
Gezellig
Gezellig? What does it mean?

Cozy. It's like, “Why do you want to go
to that bar?” “Yeah because it's gezellig.”

And then you're like, “Okay, I'm going to
go to that bar because it's gezellig.”

But it doesn't really have an English translation...
but it's like 'cozy.'
It's kind of 'cozy,' but then it's not...

It's like a comfortable place that you know
has good vibes...
So in your opinion, is Amsterdam gezellig?

It is. And it's fucking vibrant, and busy
– too busy. It, like, comes right at you

if you live in this place. It has a certain
vibe but sometimes it drives you crazy.
But in a good way.
In a good way.
It spurs creativity.
It does, absolutely.

And you guys are first and foremost that,
so thanks for showing us around the city.
It was my absolute pleasure.
Cheers, bro.

The next day they were filming for their next
video, so they invited us to join them at
the studio.
Malfoy?
Tell us what's happening, buddy.

Ok, today we are shooting a Cinemates video
and we are making a parody on famous Hollywood

blockbusters like Harry Potter, Hunger Games
et cetera, and today you guys are helping
us out through acting in the videos.

We're tuned in here for a live broadcast from
the Netherlands, where people smoke pot, eat

pancakes and ride bicycles. And let me tell
you – it's a damn good place!

It was really fun to film some sketch comedy
with Peter and Kelvin. It's something we don't

really do normally, so if you haven't seen
that video, definitely go check it out on

Cinemates' channel. It's live, there's a link
in the info box. Tell them we say hello.

Well that was a quick look at a relaxing week
here in Amsterdam. We know we didn't cover

everything, but we're planning on coming back
soon.

So if you're Dutch or you've been to Amsterdam,
tell us where we should go, what we should

do. Share your comments in the comment box
(obviously) and we'll try to factor your tips
into our next visit.

As always, if you enjoyed the video, give
it a thumbs up, share it with your friends

and subscribe to our channel for new travel
videos every Tuesday.
Amsterdam has to be one of the coolest cities in the world.
